Self-reported discomfort when using commercially targeted virtual reality equipment in discomfort distraction
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 20 November 2017

Self-reported discomfort when using commercially targeted virtual reality equipment in discomfort distraction

  • Patrick Boylan1,
  • Grainne H. Kirwan2 &
  • Brendan Rooney3 

Virtual Reality volume 22, pages309–314(2018)Cite this article

  • 603 Accesses

  • 2 Citations

  • 17 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Commercially targeted virtual reality (VR) equipment is gaining popularity and might be a viable tool for pain distraction. This experimental research aimed to discover whether active distraction techniques (such as commercially targeted VR and video games) result in reduced subjective discomfort relative to passive distraction techniques. The study examined a healthy adult population who experienced an experimentally induced discomfort task. Participants were 27 adults, 14 females and 13 males. Participants completed four tasks, a baseline measure of physical discomfort, video clip distraction (passive distraction), video game distraction (active distraction) and exploring a VR world using an Oculus Rift head-mounted display (active distraction). In all four test conditions, participants were asked to sit on a chair holding their non-dominant leg at a height of approximately 30 cm from the floor, up to a maximum of 5 min. Counterbalancing of task order was conducted to reduce effects of participant fatigue. The participants indicated significantly reduced self-reported discomfort in the active distraction tasks when compared to the passive distraction tasks. While the findings demonstrate the effectiveness of a commercially targeted VR technology in increasing pain tolerance, the relative benefits of this technology over non-immersive video games are not apparent.

Introduction

Medication for pain relief, while often successful, may not always provide optimal results. Over the last three decades, virtual reality (VR) has gained a positive reputation in the area of pain distraction (see for example Dahlquist et al. 2007; Hoffman et al. 2007, 2011; Le et al. 2011). The research in this field is now extensive, and a chart providing an overview of relevant papers has been developed by Sulea et al. (2014). Much of this research has focused on virtual reality equipment which is not targeted at the home user, but the recent popularity of technologies such as the Oculus Rift may result in more individuals having access to VR within their own homes. Few studies on pain management using the Oculus Rift have been conducted, although it demonstrates some potential for this application (Hoffman et al. 2014), and so the current study seeks to extend the research in this area using an experimental design.

The literature and associated empirical evidence indicates that when effective psychological distraction techniques are employed such as VR, discomfort levels are significantly reduced giving relief to individuals (Le et al. 2011; Sil et al. 2012). Cognitive control, and in particular distraction, has emerged as an effective adjunct non-pharmaceutical technique within the area of pain management, while research has also found it to be an effective stand-alone discomfort distractor (Hoffman et al. 2009; Jameson et al. 2011; Mühlberger et al. 2007).

Melzack and Wall (1965) put forward ‘gate control theory’—a model explaining how pain is experienced by the body. Gate control theory postulates that the central nervous system activities play a role in sensory perception; these include attention, emotion and memory. McCaul and Malott (1984) built on this theory with their distraction theory stating distraction will reduce stress; distraction requiring more attentional capacity will be more effective; and distraction is more effective on pain of low intensity. Proponents Marhrer and Gold (2009) have explained these theories, describing gate control theory—‘when pain signals travel through the body, they must pass through “nerve gates” before the body can determine the level of awareness. In other words, the level of attention paid to, the emotion associated with, and past experience of the pain all play a role in how that pain is individually interpreted’ and distraction theory—‘human beings’ limited capacity for attention, stating that an individual must attend to a painful stimulus in order for it to be perceived as painful’.

‘Attentional State’ is a commonly studied psychological variable within pain perception as distraction relies upon manipulating levels of attentional state (Villemure and Bushnell 2002). Distraction occurs when attention and concentration levels are increased and refocused; the brain’s ability to process peripheral stimuli is reduced, and deeper refocusing and concentration leads to a greater reduction in peripheral processing. Increasing cognitive stimulation leads to a reduced awareness of the physical discomfort. Therefore, if an individual can be effectively distracted, they will perceive a decrease in pain.

Despite being accepted as the most influential theory of pain, ‘gate control theory’ has not gained universal acceptance and has its opponents. The multiple resources theory proposed by Wickens (2008) states that the resources of different sensory systems function independently; consequently, it is more effective to use multisensory distractions. This lends support to the use of multimodal VR technology as an effective distraction technique.

Studies have been conducted to investigate why distraction may inhibit or decrease the perception of pain, although the precise reason why distraction works is not fully understood (Gold et al. 2007; Li et al. 2011). Interactive distraction techniques have been demonstrated to be significantly better than passive distraction at reducing pain and discomfort, although both have been found to be effective (Dahlquist et al. 2007). Distraction in the context of this study is a method which focuses and draws the participant’s concentration and attention away from an experimentally induced physical discomfort by refocusing attention elsewhere.

The phenomenon of using technology as a pain distraction technique is not a new concept; in the early 1980s, various trials were conducted using non-immersive technology including television, video and hand-held video games, with varying degrees of success. An early study conducted by Seyrek et al. (1984) investigated three different types of pain distraction techniques with dental patients. The distraction methods employed included an audio comedy programme, a video-based comedy programme and a video game. The patients exposed to the audio programme did not benefit in terms of distraction, while those who watched the video programme reported a slight increase, but those who played the video game benefited most.

In a later study, using cartoon viewing (passive) as the distraction intervention also proved positive with patients reporting reductions in pain levels (Das et al. 2005). In further studies using HMDs and full immersion VEs, researchers reported positive results for VR as a pain distraction technique (Wiederhold and Wiederhold 2007). Another study using a 3D virtual world and VR glasses showed conflicting results, as some patients felt higher levels of pain even when they were administered with the standard levels of medication (Chan et al. 2007). Some studies have reported on the phenomena that users immersed in a VE can experience their perception of time being altered and accelerated (Schneider et al. 2011; Widerhold 2005).

Much of the empirically conducted distraction studies and the literature is based on establishing whether distraction techniques work as an ‘adjunct’ pain relief enhancer in conjunction with traditional pharmaceutical medication and is particularly evident in the works of Hoffman and colleagues (see for example Hoffman et al. 2000, 2007, 2011). In a similar study to this which did not rely on or employ any other form of pain relief, Jameson et al. (2011) investigated passive distraction (television viewing) and active distraction (electronic gaming) as pain distraction techniques. The study found that active distraction lowered participant mean pain scores compared to passive and baseline measurements. The results also indicated that mean tolerance time in both active and passive distraction tasks was longer when compared to the baseline, with the active distraction task being marginally longer.

Expectations, perceptions and distraction can have a significant influence on an individual’s pain perception and play an important role in the placebo response experienced by some individuals (Goosens et al. 2005; Staats et al. 2001). Researchers have theorised that VR creates a non-pharmacologic form of analgesia as repeated associations between active analgesic and therapeutic VEs can produce a conditioned placebo analgesic response (Castro-Lopes 2009; Kalso 2006, Marhrer and Gold 2009). However, the efficacy of VR is still under investigation and the exact mechanisms behind it remain unknown (Li et al. 2011; Marhrer and Gold 2009).

Nevertheless, there is a limited understanding of whether or not VR as a distraction technique is more effective in relieving pain and discomfort than other distraction techniques (Dahlquist et al. 2010; Marhrer and Gold 2009). This research sets out to discover if increased cognitive stimulation through distraction can lead to reduced subjective discomfort in healthy adults by comparing active and passive distraction techniques. In particular, it assesses the ability of commercially oriented VR technology (the Oculus Rift HMD) to reduce subjective discomfort levels in an experimentally induced discomfort-raising act.

Hypothesis 1

There will be a significant effect of distraction condition on participants’ subjective discomfort. Specifically, we predict that the virtual reality task will be associated with the lowest level of subjective discomfort. We predict that video game, passive video and baseline conditions will be associated with higher levels of discomfort, respectively.

Hypothesis 2

The same pattern of effects will be evident in the amount of time participants hold their leg up, as an index of the pain tolerance.

Method

The research was conducted using a repeated measures design in which all participants (N = 27) experienced all four conditions. A counterbalance was conducted to eliminate the possibility of any carry-over effects because of task ordering. A pilot study with seven participants (four males and three females) was conducted, and minor amendments were made to materials as a result of pilot testing. The study was approved by two IRBs, the relevant research ethics committees in the institutions of two of the researchers.

Participants

Participants in the main study numbered 27 (13 males and 14 females) and were recruited from a student population. Ages ranged between 18 and 47 years with 81% of participants in the range 18–35 years of age and 19% between the ages of 36–47 years. Participants were excluded from the study if they were under 18 years of age. Health and safety exclusions applied for those reporting any of a number of medical conditions (such as injuries, feeling unwell, being pregnant, having recently given blood or having taken any pain relieving medication up to 24 h before testing). Participants were provided with detailed written information about the study in advance of participation and indicated their consent to participate using a written form. No incentives were used in the recruitment of participants.

Materials

Participants viewed the VR world using an Oculus Rift head-mounted display (HMD) Development Kit (Version 1.1) (Oculus VR, Inc., Irvine, CA, USA). The HMD provided a resolution of 1280 × 800 (640 × 800 per eye), delivering a diagonal field of vision (FOV) of 110 and a horizontal FOV of 90. Built into the HMD is combination of 3-axis gyros, accelerometers and magnetometers, making absolute (relative to earth) head tracking possible. A desktop PC with an i5 processor, 4 GB RAM and dual-port video card was used to host the software, virtual world and play the video clip during the experiment conditions. Auditory output was experienced using a set of stereo headphones. A 24″ monitor was used to output both the video clip and the video game.

Procedure

The testing was conducted in a psychology laboratory with participants sitting on a fixed position chair, with no swivel or wheels, facing the computer screen. Participants had room directly in front of them to raise their non-dominant leg 30 cm (12″) off the floor. In each task, participants were asked to raise their leg off the floor and hold it in position while completing the distraction tasks. Participants were timed and if they lowered their leg the task ended. No explicit or tangible incentive was offered to participants, beyond the opportunity to engage with the video, VR and game tasks. This study builds on the assumption that as pain increases this incentive becomes less appealing and thus there is a trade-off between how distracting the condition is and pain experienced. By measuring the duration for which a participant keeps their leg up, it serves as an index of their pain tolerance (given that there are no other incentives). For health and safety reasons, a maximum allowable time of 5 min was imposed. After each task condition, it was a requirement that participants walked up and down a corridor for 1 to 2 min before starting the next task condition. This was to ensure blood flow and avoid cramping in the leg. A registered nurse was available on site during testing.

The baseline task (BL) required participants to focus on a fixation cross-displayed in front of them. The video game (VG) condition involved playing of an action-adventure video game involving cartoonish animations and characters who could walk, run, drive or fly around a virtual representation of New York city. The video clip (VC) condition was created using demonstration animation and actual video game footage recorded by one of the researchers while playing the game. The footage was cut into a logical sequence following a character on a quest. The virtual reality (VR) condition allowed participants to explore a general purpose cartoonish adventure 3D virtual environment (VE) consisting of four different themed worlds. Participants could walk, run and jump as they explore the world. For both the VG and the VR conditions, participants were allowed to navigate freely while performing a task. Following each condition, the participants were requested to complete a visual analogue scale (VAS) rating their discomfort level (from ‘no discomfort’ to ‘extreme discomfort’).

Results

As the data were not normally distributed (see Table 1), nonparametric tests were used. A Friedman test was conducted to assess the subjective discomfort levels across the four conditions, and significant differences were observed: X 2 (3, N = 27) = 51.089, p < .0005. Participants reported the highest mean subjective discomfort levels during the baseline condition and the lowest levels during the virtual reality condition (see Table 2). A Bonferroni adjustment was conducted in preparation for a Wilcoxon signed-rank test, reducing the alpha level to .00834 (.05/6 = .00834). Statistically significant differences were found between all conditions except the baseline–video clip comparison and the virtual reality–video game comparison (Table 3). In all statistically significant comparisons, a medium effect size was noted.

Testing hypothesis two, a Friedman Test was conducted to compare the duration for which participants held their leg up (as in index of pain tolerance) across all four tasks BL, VC, VG and VR, revealing a variance across the tasks with a score of: X 2 (3, N = 27) = 23.571, p < .0005. The scores measuring time in seconds ranged from BL with the shortest duration (M = 221.96, SD = 85.13) to the VG task with the longest duration (M = 284.48, SD = 48.23). Summarised values are contained in Table 4. A Wilcoxon signed-rank test with a Bonferroni adjustment reducing the alpha level to .00834 (.05/6 = .00834) revealed a significant difference between the BL task and VR task in the duration for which participants held their leg up (tolerance) (z = 3.067, N—Ties = 27, p < .001, one-tailed). Analysis revealed a statistically significant and slightly larger difference between the BL task and the VG task (z = 3.233, N—Ties = 27, p < .001, one-tailed). Summarised values are contained in Table 5.

Discussion

Support was found for the use of commercially targeted virtual reality equipment in reducing subjective discomfort in an experimental discomfort inducing task. However, this reduction in self-reported subjective discomfort did not significantly differ between the virtual reality and video game conditions. As such, the primary hypothesis (that participants would report lower levels of subjective discomfort in the virtual reality condition when compared to the other three conditions) is only partially supported, despite significant differences being found between the VR and baseline and the VR and video clip conditions. It does, however, support previous research by Hoffman et al. (2014) which found that the Oculus Rift technology could be beneficial in pain control.

The second hypothesis—that active distraction induced by the non-immersive gaming task would yield lower levels of subjective discomfort than the passive distraction of the video-watching task—was supported in this study. This finding indicates that it is the active distraction element of the task, as opposed to the immersive element, which results in the reduced subjective self-reported discomfort amongst participants. The finding is consistent with previous studies (Dahlquist et al. 2007; Hoffman et al. 2007, 2011) who found active distraction techniques to be significantly better than passive distraction at reducing pain and discomfort, as well as being consistent with other research in the area (Jameson et al. 2011; Seyrek et al. 1984).

While this study demonstrates the potential for commercially targeted virtual reality equipment in pain management, it is important to note the lack of significant differences between the video game and virtual reality conditions. As video game equipment is more widely available and generally more affordable than current commercially targeted virtual reality equipment, it may be reasonable to suggest that this is a more practical option for pain management. In addition, the greater diversity of content available for video game consoles means that a much wider choice of options is available to patients, which permits them to select games and content more suited to their individual tastes. It would also reduce the possibility of boredom occurring, as new content is regularly released. However, it should also be noted that the Oculus Rift HMD used at the time of this research was a development kit (DK1) with a low-resolution screen, and future research could consider using newer commercial technology.

Alternatively, it is possible that the novelty of the technology served as a distraction in itself. When participants were recruited for the research, there was a high level of interest and general excitement at the opportunity to experience the Oculus Rift VR HMD; this may have impacted on the subjective discomfort level, especially if participants were only interested in trying the HMD. No other incentive was provided for participation in the study, even though it aimed to generate discomfort. Nevertheless, participants remained engaged. If participants were motivated to endure the discomfort so as to engage with the novel video and game experiences, then the amount of discomfort they are willing to endure was related to the extent to which the other activity was interesting, distracting and novel. It is possible that should the experience of such virtual reality equipment become more routine then its effectiveness as a distractor may be reduced, thus leading to higher perceptions of discomfort. Further research using the high-definition HMD over repeated trials is required to determine the true efficacy of the equipment as a distractor for pain and discomfort.

The study clearly shows that higher levels of interactivity can lead to lower levels of discomfort felt by participants. The results revealed that active distraction tasks are more effective than passive distraction tasks at reducing subjective discomfort levels experienced by healthy adults. The potential for using commercially targeted VR as a tool for home usage as a discomfort relief is evident; however, further studies are needed to confirm this.
